misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a road trip cost calculator that reads distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price, instead of implementing a number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100, repeated guessing, and high/low feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit this road trip cost calculator program (possibly from another exercise) as my answer to the number guessing game question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must pick a random integer between 1 and 100 using Random, then repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they get the correct number, giving "Too high" or "Too low" feedback after each incorrect guess and reporting how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: No use of Random or random number generation
No loop for repeated guessing
No conditional logic for "Too high" or "Too low" feedback
Inputs are distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of guesses between 1 and 100
Program output is the cost of driving, unrelated to a guessing game
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the problem or reusing code from a different exercise (e.g., a road trip cost calculator) instead of implementing the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start by outlining the required behavior: use Random to choose a secret number, then use a loop to repeatedly read guesses, compare them to the secret number, print "Too high" or "Too low" accordingly, and stop only when the correct guess is entered while counting attempts.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The program structure and all inputs/outputs clearly implement a road trip cost calculator and contain no elements of a number guessing game (no random number, no guesses, no feedback messages).

evidence.note: This code calculates driving cost using distance, mpg, and fuel price, and does not implement any aspect of the specified number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an unrelated problem (calculating road trip cost) instead of the required Number Guessing Game (Q2). The fundamental requirements of Q2—generating a random number, implementing a guessing loop, and providing conditional hints—are entirely missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the wrong file, or fundamentally misunderstood the assignment requirements, as the provided 'RoadTripCost' code does not attempt to solve the required Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted file must implement the logic described in Q2, including random number generation, iterative user input, and conditional feedback based on the guess.
symptoms: Code attempts to calculate travel cost.
No mention of random numbers or guessing.
Program terminates after a single set of inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misfiling or submitting code intended for a different, likely previous, assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please submit the correct file containing the implementation for the Number Guessing Game (Q2). Ensure your solution uses the `Random` class, a loop structure (like `while` or `do-while`), and `if-else` statements to check the guess.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is demonstrably for a Road Trip Cost calculation program, which is completely irrelevant to the assignment asking for a Number Guessing Game.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating travel cost, completely ignoring the problem requirements for a number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Complete task misalignment - wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a completely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of the number guessing game. The submission does not attempt to implement any of the required game logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the problem statement, submitted code from a different assignment, or misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number 1-100 and the user guesses repeatedly with high/low hints until correct.
symptoms: Code calculates road trip cost instead of implementing guessing game
No Random number generation for game
No loop for multiple guesses
No high/low comparison logic
No game termination condition for correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misreading or misunderstanding of the assignment requirements, or submission of wrong file
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The assignment requires a guessing game, not a cost calculator. Start fresh with a new program that uses Random, a loop, and conditionals to implement the game logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code is objectively unrelated to the assigned problem. It solves an entirely different problem (road trip cost) with no attempt at any of the required game components.

evidence.note: The entire submission implements a road trip cost calculator, not the required number guessing game. No game logic is present.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The submitted program calculates the cost of a road trip and does not implement the required number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100, guesses, or feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a road trip cost calculator program is an acceptable answer for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must implement a number guessing game: generate a random integer from 1 to 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until correct, and after each wrong guess print whether it was too high or too low, then report the number of guesses.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of a guessed number.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop that repeatedly asks for guesses.
No conditional logic for "Too high" or "Too low" messages.
Program terminates after computing and printing a single cost value.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem statement or copying in code for a different question, rather than implementing the specified guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem specification and start a new program that follows it step by step: create a Random object, generate a secret number from 1 to 100, use a loop to read guesses, compare each guess to the secret number, print "Too high" or "Too low" accordingly, and stop when the guess is correct while counting attempts.
related_concepts: Program design for interactive console programs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is devoted to computing road trip cost with no elements of a guessing game, so it clearly does not implement the required functionality.

evidence.note: The code is a road trip cost calculator and contains no random number generation, guessing loop, or high/low feedback logic required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Task Goal
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program ('RoadTripCost') completely unrelated to the assigned task ('Number Guessing Game'). The core concepts of randomization, loops, and conditional logic required for the game are missing.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied/submitted code from a different assignment (Road Trip Cost calculator) instead of the Number Guessing Game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must select a random number, prompt the user for guesses, and provide hints until the correct guess is made.
symptoms: Code name is 'RoadTripCost' instead of a game name.
Program prompts for distance, MPG, and price per gallon.
Program calculates road trip cost.
Lacks all necessary structures for the guessing game (Random initialization, while loop, if/else comparisons).
misconceptions.root_cause: Incorrect file submission or severe misinterpretation of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt for the Number Guessing Game and start implementation using the core requirement: setting up a random number, using a loop for repeated guesses, and using conditional statements (if/else) for feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student code is entirely devoted to calculating road trip cost and does not contain any functional components required for the number guessing game (Random, loops, comparisons).

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating road trip costs, unrelated to the assignment objective.
